Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope for Research and Educational Training in Microscopic Characterization of Nanomaterials
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award to Tuskegee University supports the acquisition of a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope which will strengthen the university's research capabilities in the emerging field of nanotechnology. This state of art equipment will support the research of not only Tuskegee's faculty and their collaborators from other institutions but also the local industry. With the capabilities of this instrument Tuskegee researchers will develop a deeper understanding of synthesis of various nanoparticles, including those derived from natural sources and their dispersion in host polymers and biological cells. Graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in cutting-edge research in nanomaterials science and engineering. This instrument along with other state-of-the-art facilities which exist at Tuskegee University will boost the university's efforts to recruit and train a large number of minority graduates, undergraduate through Ph.D. These graduates will help bring much-needed diversity to the nation's advanced technological workforce. The proposed research and instrumentation will have significant impact in education and human resources development through: (1) integration of nanotechnology research with education in all graduate programs program in Science and Engineering at Tuskegee University; (2)development of nanomaterials research at a Historically Black University; and (3) develop microscopy teaching modules for K-12 students and teachers. The minority students who graduate with an exposure to the analytical techniques using this equipment will enhance the much needed diversity in the technological workforce.

The research supported by this instrument include: a) Force Spinning Synthesis of Nanofiber Mats for Tissue Engineering Applications, b) Alignment of metal, metal oxide coated carbon nanotubes in Nylon-6 polymer single fibers and study antimicrobial/antifungal applications, c) Study the effect of alkali treatment of natural fibers for developing biodegradable composites, d) Synthesis of silica from natural sources such as rice husk and sugar cane bagasse for polymer fillers, e) Use of FE-SEM in Cancer research, and f) Study of the pharmaceutical applications of nanoparticles: Improvement of oral absorption of calcium using nanoparticles. The acquisition of the FE-SEM will also allow faculty and students involved in materials research to develop a better understanding of the material behavior at the nanometer level. The equipment will also be useful in the development of new courses in nanomaterials and various outreach activities sponsored by the Department of Materials Science and Engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: With the funding from National Science Foundation, Tuskegee University procured a state of art Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope in September 2015.  This instrument serves as an essential tool to study the nanoparticles interactions with biological cells and other organic polymer counterparts that are being investigated by Tuskegee University faculty and students. At Tuskegee University, significant efforts and resources have been invested in synthesizing a verity of nanoparticles for biological, pharmaceutical, and polymer filler applications. For example, amorphous to crystalline carbon, calcium silicates, hydroxyapatite, and calcium carbonate nanoparticles were synthesized in-house wherein the shape and size and growth patterns was precisely controlled. In addition, efforts are ongoing in developing multiferroic materials and advanced green nanocomposites from natural, renewable resources that are as strong as currently used glass-fiber reinforced composites under currently funded NSF-CREST, NSF-RISE, and NSF-PREM grants. Investigations are also underway in collaboration with other departments at Tuskegee and other universities to study the natural, renewable nanoparticles (such as calcium carbonate from eggshells, silica from rice husk, etc.) for biological and pharmaceutical applications other than polymer fillers. Addition of nanoparticles will help in improving the properties only when there is good dispersion and excellent interaction between the nanoparticles and host materials such as polymers and biological cells. This microscope at Tuskegee University campus serving as an essential characterization tool for nanomaterials to understand the dispersion, polymer-particle, and biological cells-nanoparticles interactions. Now we were able to carry out a more fundamental research understanding the science of nanoparticles for structural, biological and pharmaceutical applications. The specific research focus areas are: 1) Force Spinning Synthesis of Nanofiber Mats for Tissue Engineering Applications, 2) Alignment of metal, metal oxide coated CNTs in Nylon-6 polymer single fibres and study antimicrobial/antifungal applications, 3) Study the effect of alkali treatment of natural fibres for developing biodegradable composites, 4) Synthesis of silica from natural sources such as rice husk and sugar cane bagasse for polymer fillers, 5) Use of FE-SEM in Cancer research, and 6) Study of the pharmaceutical applications of nanoparticles: Improvement of oral absorption of calcium using nanoparticles.

 

Intellectual Merit : Development of various nanomaterials including nanoparticles from waste resources such as eggshells, coconut powder, rice husk and sea shells and their application in biomedical, electronic and automotive applications. At Tuskegee University, efforts are focused on the following research areas:

  1. 3D Printed Supercapacitor from Packaging waste derived activated carbon
  2. Smart Nanostructured Films for Sensitive Chemical Detection and Analysis
  3. Development of bioactive tissue engineering scaffolds
  4. Effect of ball milling on Coconut shell sourced carbon powder
  5. Comparison of surface morphologies of cellulose and silica extracted from agricultural waste.
  6. Microscopic analysis of carbon/glass fiber reinforced polymer nanocomposites
  7. Surface characterization of nanoparticles infused PLA fibers produced by force spinning
  8. Fractured analysis of carbon fibers reinforced with graphene and clay particles
  9. Determination of the nanomechanical properties of epoxy-chlorobenzene microcapsules using nanoindentation technique

10.  Processing and performance of carbonfiber compoistes reinforced with CNTs added high temperature bismalemide polymers under ambient and relative humid conditions

11.  Synthesis of porous carbon from spent coffee grinds

12.  Sonochemical effect CaCO3 in the presence of H2O2

13.  The Effects of altering drying methods of bio-nanocellulose on morphology.

14.  Surface morphology of modified microcrystalline cellulose (MCC) and the effect of alkaline surface treatment of flax fibers.

15.  Fabrication and Characterization of ZnO nanoparticle by FESEM

16.  FSEM for Micrography of Carbon Nanoparticles Derived from Banana Peel

 

Broader Impacts: Several faculty, graduate and undergraduate students were trained in how to use this state of art field emission electron microscope and analyze the data for their research. A   large number of minority graduates, undergraduate through Ph.D., well exposed to synthesis and microscopic characterization of advanced materials. More than 20 research articles and one Ph.D dissertation and three M.S theses were published to benefit the scientific community.
